reviews.author: datboi
reviews.title: i want a refund from HKUST and i want to die
reviews.comment_content:
If you expect to learn something from this course, prepare to be disappointed. The content from this course is so shit and stupid I actually want to die.

The PPT slides are just walls of text, and the exams and quizzes test every tiny fact from the slides, so if you like memorizing PPT slides you will love this course!

Also there is like 2 huge chapters that isnt even about buildings - VR and microsensors.

The shit he teaches is like a middle school presentation. (stupid topic, terrible organization, poor communication, and zero effort)

At the end of the course, he tries to bribe the students by giving a free ebook/audiobook that you can find on google
reviews.comment_teaching:
yeah... his teaching is shit.

His horrible accent is unclear and unintelligible.
He just reads off the slides or goes off topic. He is so boring I just want to die... too bad this course takes attendance and require to turn on cam, or else I would have just ditched all the lectures.

All he talks about is microsensors ALOT in every lecture. But yet I feel I have learnt nothing about it.

He always just plays youtube videos during lectures. I dont mind the videos, but they are all useless - for 3 lectures straight, he just played advertisements for Alexa and other dumb products.


In lectures after midterm, he name-called people who got low scores... he is evil and cold-blooded with no concern for student's well-being.


also he is a real bitch about camera policy
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Policy:
(1)  Attendance of the online lecture via Zoom with the camera turned-on, 15% and Quiz via Canvas Quizzes
(2) Mid-term Examination 35 %
(3) Final Examination 50 %

the quizzes and exams are just testing how well you memorize every minute detail of the PPT.
- In the midterm, there was a question about the year microsensors were discovered or something like that. Which is kinda dumb and irrelevant to the scope of the course...
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework.
But prepare to memorize all the PPT content to regurgitate in the exams and quiz

reviews.author: GK
reviews.title: Better than MECH1906
reviews.comment_content: Less diverge and more focused on building in Mechanical engineering. Quite a fun course if you are interested. However, the 50 pages lecture notes may scare you off.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor himself is very nice. He is willing to answer any questions and chat with us even outside class. His office is open for us for most of the time. You can even find him whenever you are free to chat with him with the things that are not even related to the course. He is more like a Secondary teacher than a lecturer so you are expecting him to be a little bit different from standard lecturer. For example, he would require the students who attend the lessons not to eat or chat in the class. So you may have to behave yourself if you attend his class.
However, in the lecture, he would not provide much information outside of the lecture notes. So you may find it boring to attend his lessons
reviews.comment_grading:
5 Assignments which involves in simple calculations
1 Midterm exam
1 Final exam
For the two exams, they consists of 40% Short questions and 60% Calculation. The calculation is almost the same as the calculations done in the assignments. So this part of score is a must-get score. The short questions are the materials from the lecture notes. They can be recited easily if you can find the pattern. The grading is also great. I got an A+ in return of simple revision.
reviews.comment_workload: No attendance will be taken. No worry on not attending the lessons. The assignments are easy to do if you have some physics background. You can do it if you don't have such background by searching inside the lecture notes. You may have to notice the deadlines of assignment. With understanding the examination pattern, you can recite very little things from the lecture notes and get a good grade. That is why the work load is very very small.

reviews.author: HZ
reviews.title: DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE
reviews.comment_content:
Brief Summary:      

Functions of buildings; intelligent and green buildings for contemporary living; sustainability and financial assessments of building systems; building systems: building materials/indoor comfort and health/lighting/water supply/information; security, energy use and supply for buildings; renewable energy for future; energy supply, energy conservation; impact of technology development on contemporary living.

Course Topics:

(1) Introduction

(2) Urban Living

(3) Building Systems

(4) Intelligent/Smart Buildings

(5) Micro Sensors Technology for Buildings

(6) Green Buildings

(7) VR, AR, MR and Metaverse (Links to an external site.):  for next-generation engineering design (automotive, building and construction)

(8) Heat Transfer in Buildings

(9) Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration

(10) MEMS micromirror for VR/AR/MR and self-driving car by TA, Wenhao Chen; Electric system for Buildings and Micro gyro for Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) of buildings

(11) Water Supply for Buildings

(12) Siting and Construction (optional),

(13)* Guest lecture by the manager, Hong Kong Center for Construction Robotics (Links to an external site.) : on 10 May 2022
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is insanely bad.

The fact that he includes attendance WITH CAMERAS ON as part of the grading is genuinely appalling considering the state of his lectures. His accent grates upon the ears and you won't want to listen to a single second of the lecture, not that it matters anyways because he just reads off slides and yells at students to switch their cameras on.

For anyone out there who enjoy being bored to tears for three hours a week while learning fuck all, this course is for you. If not, PLEASE AVOID.

In fact, one of my main motivations for writing this review is to rant about how shit this professor is. He probably got forced by the UST to take up a teaching assignment and now he's taking out his frustration on us poor students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Policy:

(1)  Attendance of the online lecture via Zoom with the camera turned-on, 15% and Quiz via Canvas Quizzes (Bonus: ask good question via Zoom Chat)

(2) Mid-term Examination 35 %:  online exam at 10:30am~11:50am, 29 March 2022

(3) Final Examination 50 %:  online exam at 9am~9:30am, 18 May 2022 according to Academic Registry.Links to an external site.

Bonus point for those highly-motivated students to do the project with PG students for Smart HVAC system or the UROP project under newly established HK Center for Construction Robotics: https://www.hkcrc.hk/ (Links to an external site.)
reviews.comment_workload: If you want a good grade, you need to memorise A LOT. Basically just memorise everything that is on the lecture slides of which there are thousands.

reviews.author: axol
reviews.title: Misleading Course Title
reviews.comment_content: The course should be titled 'IoT and Microsensors for Contemporary Living' instead of 'Buildings for Contemporary Living'. Although there are various topics like building systems, siting n construction, green building, water supply, etc., the professor was obsessed with those two topics (iot and microsensors), resulting in less focus in other materials, especially the later ones as it felt like we just passed through them without paying much attention.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor was definitely passionate abt teaching the course and also invited several lecture guests, but instead of drawing students' attention, all those side materials would only be a burden as they're somewhat included in the exams. Prof's delivery was boring, can't really stay focused for more than half an hour, and with his accent, it became worse.
reviews.comment_grading: Reasonable grading, I suppose. At first, we were told that all the grades were taken from the midterm, final, and a group project, but at the beginning, he told us to watch a talk and write an essay from it, not really sure if it affected the grading or not.
reviews.comment_workload: Apart from the midterm and final exams, there's only one group project which can either be okay or super burdening depending on your teammates and the topics you choose. We were given 20 or 30 smth topics to choose from, and maybe choose the one that you know the most or at least passionate abt since the topics could completely be unrelated to the course materials and you have to do a lot of research by yourself. In the end, we were told to write a 10+ page report and present it using ppt. There will be one or two progress checking to see how your team was doing by submitting a tentative report. A day or two before final submission, the instruction of the report's format changed and so some adjustments needed to be made which was annoying

reviews.author: ちきばん
reviews.title: IoT + VR/AR/MR/Metaverse for Contemporary Living :)
reviews.comment_content:
NB: I took this course with the understanding that its main content is going to be IoT + XR (VR/AR/MR + Metaverse) (after reading reviews here), and that I was prepared to recite hundreds of slides of walls of words.
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE if you cannot make these commitments.

What was on the syllabus at the start of the semester:
[Lecture Numbers] Topic
• [1-3] Introduction
• [4-5] Urban Living
• [5-7] Building Systems
• [7-9] Smart Buildings
• [9-11] Green Buildings
• [12-16] Micro Sensors Technology (IoT) for Buildings
- - - Mid-term syllabus - - -
• [17-19, 23] XR+Meta (VR/AR/MR and Metaverse) for next-generation engineering design (automotive, building and construction), including a lecture by one of the postgrad TAs on MEMS Micromirror (LiDAR) for VR/AR/MR and Self-driving Car
• [19-20] Heat Transfer in Buildings
• [21-23] Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration
• [24-25] Water Supply for Buildings
- - - Final syllabus (with 20% of questions from mid-term syllabus) - - -
• [Marked as optional] Siting and Construction, including Respirable Crystalline Silica Safety For Construction
• [Skipped] Electric System for Buildings, and Micro-gyro for Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) of Buildings
• [Hidden topic] Renewable Energy

Remarks:
1. Marked as optional: On syllabus, has slides, no teaching, tested in quizzes, not tested in exams
2. Skipped: On syllabus, no slides, no teaching, not tested in quizzes, not tested in exams
3. Hidden topic: Not on syllabus, has slides, no teaching, tested in quizzes, not tested in exams

See Teaching for what was actually covered (topics which the instructor spent excess time covering).

I give the content a D here because he covered the topics that made me take this course in 9 out of 25 lectures (plus discussions in 8 other lectures) (i.e. he primarily covered what he was supposed to cover in this course in only 14 out of 25 lectures - not even 60% of the semester!).
reviews.comment_teaching:
First of all, to be fair, the instructor's Taiwanese accent is acceptable, considering there are other instructors and TAs with accents so worse that you struggle to understand what s/he is talking about.

What was actually covered
[Lecture Numbers] Topic
• [1-11] Safeguarding yourself from Covid
• [1] Metaverse
• [2] Air purifier
• [3] Guest lecture by CEO, KFIAQ (a company that produces air purifiers): How their air purifiers work (basically their pitch, with its content TESTED in the mid-term!!!)
• [4] Metaverse, Crypto trading, Cancer detection by Prof. Dennis Lo at CUHK
• [5] McRefugees, Hydrogen cars, AutoCAD
• [6] His daughter's Tinkercad house, 911, Ceiling failure in an MAE office
• [7] Russian invasion of Ukraine, Stock prices of a waterproof coating company, IoT
• [8] Metaverse, AIoT, Scratch, The landscape of the building industry, Amazon Echo
• [9] Amazon Ring, Wi-Fi×AI (IoT) Sensor research by MIT
• [11] Towngas meters
• [12] XR+Meta (VR/AR/MR and Metaverse), A15 Bionic VS MTK Dimensity 9000, HKUST EC (but he's not sponsored) (so he keeps saying "I have too much money now! If you want to make money contact me!"), Sizes of cells, Trade War
• [13] Importance of TSMC and semiconductors, AtomSemi CPU in China, How Zuck (Meta) and DNA sequencing chip makers get rich, Documentary on the manufacturing of 45nm chips
• [14] Documentary on the manufacturing of 45nm chips (relevant)
• [15] Net worth of unicorns like Berkeley Lights
• [16] EWOD, Liquid Lens Cam Module on Mi MIX Fold, XPeng, Masayoshi Son's vision on IoT @ ARM TechCon
• [17] Bitcoin, Luxvue (Apple-acquired Micro LED startup)
• [18] XR Application other than Buildings, Replacement for the obsolete LCD
• [19] AI Ethics, AI Chatbots, NVIDIA HoloDeck, Crypto, Sandbox (Metaverse)
• [20] Heat sinks and vapour chambers
• [21] Rokid AR Glasses
• [22] Legionnaires' Disease
• [23] RoboSense, UROP, Liquid cooling in PC
• [24] Sandbox (Metaverse)
• [25] Guest lecture by Manager, HKCRC (Hong Kong Center for Construction Robotics): Introduction to Internship @ HKCRC (with additional coverage by instructor), XR+Meta, Rokid AR Glasses
• [Optional seminar] Guest lecture by VP, Rokid: Application of their AR glasses in smart manufacturing (yep another pitch)

He was so fervent in covering the de facto topics above that he usually spent ⅓ of the lecture time (sometimes taking over the entire lecture) to go off-topic, leaving no time left to answer students' questions. (this was also caused by his wasting some time by typing his verbal question on the Zoom chat)

I give the teaching a D here because besides going off-topic, the instructor spent little time covering a couple of keywords on each slide - basically walls of words - in each lecture. That was how he finished one of the topics with >100 slides in just 4 lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes + Attendance (15% of course grade)
Two open-book quizzes (one quiz before each exam) to complete within the day of release (around a week before each exam). Your scores in the quizzes basically determine your score in the 15%, so you will want to maximise your scores there. The attendance part is just to FORCE you to TURN ON YOUR CAMERA during each lecture (however boring the content sounds like) so as not to lose marks here. By the way, he called out the names of students who got below mean scores in mid-term and those who never turned on their webcams IN CLASS for more than once.

Mid-term (35% of course grade; Closed book)
• Number of slides of walls of words: 283
• Mean: 77.68
• Highest: 98.2
• SD: 14.68
• My score: 82.67

Final (50% of course grade; Closed book)
• Number of slides of walls of words: 486
• Mean: 76.26
• Highest: 96.67
• My score: 85

+ Bonus points for students undertaking the UROP project for Smart HVAC system or UROP projects under the HKCRC (claimed by the instructor)

My final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
No tutorials. Just two 1.5h lectures every week. Other than doing two things near the exams: cramming the walls of words on slides and doing the quizzes, the workload is zero. What else can you ask for?

By the way, he supplies you with some optional reading materials (websites, videos, etc.) on the topics in the syllabus after covering them in lectures. None of them were tested.

reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching of the two professors are boring, mainly due to the lecture slides. You may just read the slides yourself without listening to them.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments (5 pieces) 10%
Midterm 30%
Final 60%

The midterm paper consists of 4 short questions and 2 calculation questions which are really very similar to the assignments. As for the short questions, although it was told listing the points with explanation was enough, they were unpredictable. For instance, one question asked about the constituent compounds of natural gas without asking for explanation.

Structure of the exam paper is just similar to the midterm paper, except having a double of the number of questions. What's more, one short question required more than explanation in words but also a diagram. As for the calculation questions, although it was told that they were very similar to the assignments, in fact, ALL OF THE THEM in the exam paper are DIFFERENT from those in assignments. Concepts or ideas of those questions in the paper may be included in the lecture slides instead. Some of them may confused us as their situations were similar to examples shown in the slides but the ideas or concepts were totally unrelated. They were taught in DSE physics lessons instead, like mgh = 0.5 mv^2 (conversion of PE to KE).

In short, it is encouraged not to trust in professors.

Additionally, should you find anything ambiguous in the papers, just ask the TA or professors. They may then explain to you, although Moses may actually want to blame you for not reading the questions carefully...

Regarding my performance:
Assignment 1: 19/25
Assignment 2 - 5: 25/25
Midterm: 51/100 (below ~1sd)
Final: ?
Grade: B+ (It seems that I have got a pretty high score in the final exam. It may be so lucky that I have studied physics in college.)
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload. There are only 2 assignments before midterm and 3 after that. Questions are not hard.

reviews.author: haha2015
reviews.comment_content: It covers almost every area of contemporary buildings. All the stuffs are factual yet USELESS. If you really want to learn something, do NOT enroll in this course. It is a waste of time.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures are boring and useless. You can read the powerpoint slides yourselves. The powerpoint slides are full of words.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair.

Based on assignments, midterm and final

Exams consist of short questions (40%) and calculation problems (60%).
All the short questions are "list five items" questions, which are easy. Most of the calculation problems are similar to those in the assignments.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 assignments in total.
The assignments are TIME-CONSUMING if you really complete them yourselves as the questions are NOT covered in the lectures. You need to figure out the solutions yourselves.

A lot of memorizing for the exams. Moreover, the stuffs are boring and useless, which makes the revision torturing.

reviews.author: SL
reviews.comment_content:
There are around 22 chapters about building, energy, and physics calculations. The PPT slides are full of words, pictures. You will probably not willing to read the messy PPTs and the contents are just some facts that you may find on the internet.
You cannot learn anything from this course as it only requires you to recite the materials and solve some calculation problems that are not taught.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Moses's lesson is completely useless as he will just read out the slides or talk about nonsenses stuffs that are not regarding the course.
He is not quite willing to help students and his answer to your questions are not quite useful at most of the time.
reviews.comment_grading: As the workload for reciting the materials is quite high, he grading is just fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 5 assignments in total.
The assignments are quite hard for you to finish as there are nothing for you to follow on the lecture slides and you have to solve it by yourself or searching online.
Have both midterm and final exam.
High workload for you to study for the exams as you have to study 22 PPTs with 50 pages and 5 assignments without any answers distributed.

reviews.author: H_Barnes
reviews.comment_content: 22 chapters about building, energy, and physics calculations. PPT slides are full of words, in point form though.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Moses hates late-comers. Chatting/whispering is not allowed in class and he will stop anytime if students are found doing so.

In class he simply goes through all the slides one by one, words by words so it is boring attending the lectures. But it saves time to review the PPT on your own.

Moses is more like a high-school teacher than a professor in a sense that he is strict in many ways and has lots of rules to follow. It is sometimes annoying to listen to his rules.

But he is passionate helping the students off the class. He will even explain the questions at the start of the exam, but it is not allowed to ask questions afterwards.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not bad.  The grading is based on the 5 assignments given, midterm and final exam. I got A- for results at above mean (all the 5 assignments and midterm).

For the exams, 40% are Short questions while the others are basic physics calculations. Short questions are like "list any 5 (advantages/disadvantages/examples, etc.) given in the notes...", which is quite easy if you have reviewed the slides with more than 5 points. So it is a very good strategy and practice to recite those slides with great effort before the exam.

The other questions are calculation very similar to the assignments, which the required equations can be found in the PPT. Overall the exams are easy to handle so the grade is not bad if you bear the studying tactics in mind.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only 5 assignments are given on every other week so it does not have a big load. The assignments are simple calculations taught in class and are easy to handle if studied well.

(He does not give any answers/solutions for the assignments so it is better to do it by yourself and have a better review before the exam.)

reviews.author: kenken
reviews.comment_content:
It's about buildings and covers some things about smart technology. There are many powerpoint slides and lots of information. I think it's a bit like liberal studies in DSE.

I think the content is quite boring as I don't like seeing lots of words in the notes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Lee doesn't speak english well but is passionate at teaching. The things he teach is mostly stuff in ppt notes.

reviews.author: Vin_nkwong
reviews.title: A good note sheet is the most important thing
reviews.comment_content:
24 topics in total and around 60 pages of slides per topic.
The slides are full of words, only a few pictures.
Also, the content is actually quite boring if you are not interested in buildings.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Moses basically puts everything into the slides and he reads on the slides during the class. No need to worry if you skip his class, you can find everything in the slides.
Not bad for a common core course.
reviews.comment_grading:
You can bring note sheet(s) in midterm and final.
Just write down EVERYTHING in the slides.

Midterm and final have 5~6 questions and most of them required exact wordings from the slides. So the note sheet plays a very important role in the midterm and final.

Bring everything from the slides into midterm and final will guarantee a grade for you.

Luckily I copied everything on my note sheet in both midterm and final, got an A+ for this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload. 5 Assignments in total.
No quiz no attendance.
As I said the course materials are all in the slides, just work hard on the slides. Your effort will pay off.
